conclusion: Use the relationship between volume, temperature, and pressure of an ideal gas.
Initial conditions at state A: V_A = V_0, T_A = T_0, p_A = p_0.
Line segment AB is parallel to the volume axis, indicating constant volume V_0.
Line segment BC extends from the origin to point B, indicating an increase in volume.
Identify initial conditions at state A: gas is at equilibrium with initial volume and temperature.
Since AB is parallel to the volume axis, volume remains constant at V_0; therefore, pressure p_A = p_0.
Since volume is doubled, pressure p_B must also double to maintain the same volume.
Use ideal gas law pV = nRT.
Since volume is doubled, number of moles n must also double.
Since pressure p_B is double that of p_A, final pressure p_B = 2p_0.
Verify relationship between given conditions and derived pressure at state B.
Final answer: pressure of gas at state B is 2p_0.
